Situation1: Their partner faces a tough decision at work and seeks advice and encouragement.
Situation2: They scan items during a slow afternoon with a few customers in line.
Story: I stand behind the register, the soft beep of the scanner filling the quiet store. My husband’s voice echoes in my mind from our rushed phone call during my break—he’s anxious, facing a tough decision at work, and he needs me. He asked if I could talk, just for a few minutes, to help him sort through his thoughts. I want to be there for him, to offer the comfort and advice he’s always counted on. But now, as I glance at the small line forming at my register, I feel the weight of my other role. Each customer expects me to be focused, to ring up their groceries without error, to smile and wish them a good day. My phone vibrates in my pocket—another message from him, maybe. My heart aches to support him, but my hands are busy scanning items, my mind split between the needs of the person in front of me and the person I love most. I feel the tension rising, torn between being the attentive wife he needs and the reliable cashier my job demands.
